text: Debut of Linear Programming In 1948, at a conference at the University of Wisconsin- Madison, George B. Dantzig gave a talk: “Programming in a linear structure.” After the talk, the chairman called for discussion. One statistician raised hand and said: ‘But we all know the world is nonlinear.” Having uttered this devastating criticism of Dantzig’s model, he majestically sat down.
